comments:
History of what happened: I opened a .project file in Windows Notepad. Windows
assigned Notepad as the default program with which to open .project files. After
this my eclipse platform did not want to open my java-projects. I managed to
"unassign" the .project files, but the problem remained (eclipse didn't want to
open the projects due to a problem with the .project files - this happened for
all my projects). I then deleted the eclipse platform from my system and
re-installing it, thinking that this might solve the problem. However, after
re-installation I encountered a fatal error as listed below in the log-file.
PLEASE HELP ME!!!

It looks like the conversion from plugin.xml to manifest.mf failed.
*** Bug 85657 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Maybe a duplicate of bug 57298.

Crimson appears as the XML parser, but you are using Java 1.5.0, which is
supposed to use Xerces. Have you tweaked your JRE install by adding some version
of crimson.jar or other libraries to the lib/ext/directory?
Sorry, I meant the "lib/ext directory" inside the JRE.

(In reply to comment #3)
> Maybe a duplicate of bug 57298.
> 
> Crimson appears as the XML parser, but you are using Java 1.5.0, which is
> supposed to use Xerces. Have you tweaked your JRE install by adding some version
> of crimson.jar or other libraries to the lib/ext/directory?

Adding the crimson.jar found at http://xml.apache.org/dist/crimson/ to the
lib/ext directory of the JRE solved the problem. There is a version of
crimson.jar shipped with Java 1.5.0, but I had a look at the dates of the class
files contained in it, and these dates are earlier than the dates of the class
files contained in the crimson.jar found at the above url.

Thank you for the help. I appreciate it very much.

> Adding the crimson.jar found at http://xml.apache.org/dist/crimson/ 
> to the lib/ext directory of the JRE solved the problem.

You got me wrong, I was not suggesting you added/updated crimson.jar, but
ensured you had not added one there before.

> There is a version of
> crimson.jar shipped with Java 1.5.0,

No, there isn't... you must have added it there manually. See:

http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/guide/xml/jaxp/JAXP-Compatibility_150.html

You should be able to run with no crimson.jar.
